what are you trying to improve here? is there an inherent problem with cephadm shell? is it going away? I am also worried about installing ceph-common on the host machine in CI only to hide some issue that appears without this package installed

Option 4: start the cephadm container ourselves, do what we need from it, clean it up.

That one I prefer.

Thanks for elaborating on the issue.

Basically the issue is that "cephadm shell" runs a docker container for running the command, the issues we see with cephadm deployment is on ,,looped'' commands where we add e.g. 3 OSDs. The issue is that we run the second command before cephadm shell is able to clean up after itself.
Option 1: add delay
Option 2: do it in one run - but I was struggling with some errors - which probably show up due to the docker run/podman run nature of cephadm shell
Option 3: install client and do it 5 times faster

Which one do you prefer? ;-)
We can even pause for longer, it will not hurt.
How much longer? 5 seconds seems like an overkill (given we have a couple of loops)

We have 3,4,3 loop items which gives us 2,3,2 pauses, 7 pauses in total. Times 5 this is 35 seconds. Times 4 is 28 which sounds very reasonable to spare.

Anyhow, what about pauses between tasks? Is Ansible "slow enough" to always "pause" for more than a second? If so, we could just replicate the expected "pause" of Ansible itself and reuse that in the loop. If we don't know, we might want to pause outside of the loops as well.

I also came up with Option 5 - template a script to pass to cephadm shell (I think it allows piping with bash) which avoids calling cephadm shell more than once, saving us time and sanity. WDYT?
May we get all actions with cephadm in a single task then? This way we would avoid any instance of this issue.

doc/source/command-objects/backup.rst.message:
I dont like that we have just made a positional argument an optional one. what do you think about this instead, i have 2 suggestions.

1) we keep volume as positional

we try to find <volume>, if we have a match then restore to that volume, this keeps the same behaviour.
If no match is found, then we create a new one with name=parsed_args.volume
We can debug or info messages saying that no match was found so the user knows something unusual happened

2) we add a --new-volume flag

The flow would be `os backup restore <backup> <volume> --new-volume`

If the flag is used, we create a new volume with name <volume>.
If no flag is used then we restore to <volume>. If <volume> doesn't exist then we error out.

Also, volume is allow to be created with the same name. In the case of suggestion 1, we cannot create a new volume whose name is the same as a existing volume name, because finding is before creating.

Hi, Steve. I thought for a while， I agree with keeping <volume> as positional， without <volume>, a new volume named "None" will be create to restore to, this maybe an unusual behave for users.
But I have some questions about your first suggestion. In the case of suggestion 1, new volume will be created if no volume match the input, but in one case, if users want to restore to a existing volume but input a wrong name, a new volume with the wrong name will be also created and the restoring will be also implemented, this is not what the users want.
Comparing with suggestion 1, I think suggestion 2 can avoid the problem I mentioned above, Personally， I think your second suggestion is better, what do you think?
Yes, I will do it following your second suggestion, Thanks!

ohhh great points about name being non-unique! 


OK - option #2 it is -- if you like the suggestion, of course

this is a real world example of a multistropt supported by nova

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/pci/devspec.py#L201-L211=
[pci]
passthrough_whitelist = {"address":"*:0a:00.*",
                        "physical_network":"physnet1"}
passthrough_whitelist = {"address": {"domain": ".*",
                                     "bus": "02",
                                     "slot": "01",
                                    "function": "[0-2]"},
                        "physical_network":"net1"}
passthrough_whitelist = {"vendor_id":"1137","product_id":"0071"}

the vlaues are json stings
the adress filed can be a simple string in which case it optionally supprot bash style wildcard * glob syntax

the embeded adress filed can also be a dictionary
in which case it suppot python regex format in the sub fileds

in all of the above can be used together

and when the above config section is parsed it is formed into a python list contraing 3 strings that contain json so this is parsed in 2 steps

first oslo.cofig constructs the list of opaque strings form the .conf file
then nova does a json loads one each item in the list of strings and marshaels the contented into python object that model the  whitelist and adress semantics.

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/pci/whitelist.py#L55-L83=

specs/zed/transaction-tracking.rst.message:
nit: For some requests there is a way, using the workers table. Though the information there is probably insufficient for what you want or maybe the problem is that it only stores information for operations that are cleanable.

In that table we have:
- When the request was started
- Last time a service (API/SCH/VOL) received the request
- Cinder Service that last received the request (for API it's empty)
- Resource type (volume, snapshot, etc)
- Resource ID

nit: I think this can be misleading, because it's not really the scheduler's task flow, it's still in the API (cinder/volume/flows/api/create_volume.py) and this sentence could make someone think that the code did the RPC call to the scheduler.

I was talking about the scheduler's task flow for create volume here:
https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/scheduler/flows/create_volume.py
Would be good to add both cinder APIs taskflow and scheduler's taskflow points here like APIs taskflow calls scheduler's taskflow
nit: manager's
Done
We currently do that with the workers table, albeit the current cleanup mechanism is insufficient in terms of supported states and how it resolves those situations (mostly setting resource to error).
Creating should be moving to error now (if it's not currently broken).

Why not use, possibly extending, the Workers table?
Currently we can get a lot of information (only for some operations) from there.

It looks like the workers table isn't used for much.  Also it has individual rows for each state change and there is no progress ability.

The volume transactions table should have 1 row that is updated with the current status, instead of creating a new row for a change in status.  Maybe the 2 tables can coexist where the workers table points to a transaction table entry via foreign key.  The goal is to have every volume action tracked.  It looks like the workers table is a locking mechanism for clustering as well as a rudimentary cleanup mechanism to get volumes out if an 'ing' state into error state at next startup.
?: something
Done

Would this be a soft-delete table (like most of our tables) or a hard-delete one (like the workers table)?

I like hard deletion because it's self-cleaning, but from an operator's point of view I can see the great benefit of keeping transaction record there, as one could see the operations that have been done on a specific resource, and if we add the request ID to the records then it could be even better.
Would be good to mention this point in the spec so we can differentiate between the workers (hard delete) and transactions (soft delete) tables.
I think I would like it to be a soft delete table as I can use it to help track down why some transactions have failed in production.
This is an interesting idea.  It would make sense to consolidate actions that should happen on the start/end of transactions: send notification, track in DB, etc.
Looks like the draft is only up to this point for now.

ops_openstack/core.py.message:
Not sure if this will break anything, since it's technically not backwards compatible.

It's really confusing with yaml + python's weak typing, because we don't know explicitly if "unset" means the key is not present, the key is present and the value is None, or if it's present and defaulting to an empty string (which is "falsey".

The current assumptions from engineers appear to be that empty string also counts as "unset" for these purposes.

I don't think we can extend this logic to "falsey" values for other config types though (int, bool, float), because False for a bool, and 0 for a number are falsey, but clearly it's possibly they were explicitly set to False or 0.
Removing this after discussion that cleared this up - "key not present" == no default and value not explicitly set by user.

Create a large file on /var to almost fill it, leave say around 200 MB free so it is about 99% full.  Then force a crash dump while watching the serial console. That explanation doesn't help.  Reword: It needs 2048M because kdump doesn't use a separate stripped down initramfs like it does in CentOS.  The initrd.img link always points to /boot/1/initramfs.

Part of me is skeptical that this is going to work correctly when patching the kernel to different versions in the future.  Is the initramfs at /boot/1 always going to contain compatible modules for the crash kernel?
It's more than just the size of the initramfs, it's also not needed modules such as nic drivers loading and allocating memory.
I think if the normal kernel can boot up, then crash kernel will boot up with  /boot/1/initramfs.  here the problem is initramfs is too big,  that will need more memory.

Also regarding the /boot/1 initramfs, is it always the initramfs that's in use for the booted kernel?  Can't say I understand the difference how the /boot/0 and /boot/1 mechanisms are supposed to work, as in when is one used instead of the other.  If we end up booting the /boot/0 kernel does that mean that crash dumping won't work since /boot/1/initramfs is not compatible?  If there are limitations to this, it should be documented.

Good question.  I am not clear either. Maybe Mark and Hongxu know the details.

Agree.  Setting aside 2GB just to get the crash kernel booted seems like a lot.  Also does it use a separate initramfs for the crash kernel like it does in CentOS?  If so, make sure to strip out any unnecessary kernel driver modules from it such as the network drivers.  We just need to access disk to dump the core.

Hi, Jim & Mark
I had filed a new defect to track the initramfs that will be created for kdump.
https://jira.windriver.com/browse/CGTS-35960
That's a Wind River internal defect which is useless here. There needs to be a bugboard bug filed.

It really should be using a separate stripped down initramfs for the crash kernel.  Why?  Because we need to minimize the risk of the crash kernel itself crashing.  For example, the problem could be with a nic driver, and if it loads in the crash kernel and crashes, you get nothing.  The kdump initramfs should be the bare minimum needed to get the vmcore onto disk.  But you say (paraphrasing) "we can't make it work because there is a bug that we haven't been able to solve".  Is this bug tracked?  Did an architect sign off on this inferior approach instead as a workaround?

It is 2G because we use the initramfs /boot/1/initramfs.

Oh, interesting... so you can specify prefixed guys like

 sha1:...
 sha256:...
 sha512:...

But if you go unprefixed, it can handle *either* sha1 or sha512? I wonder if we should add some length-detection for sha256, too...

Do we have test coverage for this? The gate's reports make me think no...

Mainly worried because this is our primary upgrade path.

i wonder if modifying if someone adds "fizzbuzz" to the list of algos, if we're better off modifying the configuration or refusing to start?

I could see an argument that at somepoint in the future if we deprecate a algo that used to be allowed we might want to log a warning before we invalidate and refuse to start with the unsupported config.

I can appreciate the argument for consistency with tempurl. FWIW, I think my original thinking there was that if we ever add more supported digests, ops might want to be able to add to their config ahead of upgrading Swift, and have it take effect whenever they actually get to upgrading the node.

I'd be fine with turning up the severity, though. Or even turning it into a hard error, w/e.

The next patch adds sha1 to deprecated so it'll warn. Left it out here because we had nothing atm to deprecate.

The idea is, the digest can be prepended, so some of them might stil be useful. But thinking about it, it might be nice to fail to start if there is a misconfiguration, like a digest we don't support. I'll raise an error in it.

Most of this is pulled from the tempurl code and so it also just warns, not errors out. But might be worth the change in both.
Still need to think about whether to fail to start on this or not. Currently we don't in tempurl.. but maybe we should be (as clay mentions).
Nit: in case of the unsupported algorithms - maybe the logging should be error in that case? Warning if deprecated, error if using unsupported? Goes both for tempurl and formpost.
So these sigs are always hex and the base64 stuff I added for tempurl is not available here, yeah?

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/api/controll.message: I'm afraid that if we remove this host_has_last_mon check we may be able to force lock the host with the only one ceph monitor remaining.

But if we have only 1 ceph monitor out of 3 available (Standard/Storage), ceph won't work. It needs 2 out of 3 at least to work.

That is why we need to not allow locking the second ceph monitor. But if user forces it, then we allow it.

For AIO-SX and AIO-DX there is only one ceph monitor configured, so this last mon check does not apply.
I was told that the platform shouldn't allow locking the host (even with the force flag) when the host has the last Ceph monitor up. May need to confirm with @Bob the expected behavior.

It is a 'force' command. So, yes, it will lock even if this is the last monitor.
I have tested this change on all possible setups and could lock/unlock the hosts as expected.

In Storage/Standard setups it is possible to lock one host that has ceph monitor. To lock the second host with ceph monitor simultaneously, we have to use the 'force' parameter.

Ah, the yaml schema in the LAT source code appears to mandate a non-null value:

Quoting from /opt/LAT/SDK/sysroots/x86_64-wrlinuxsdk-linux/usr/share/genimage/data/pykwalify/genimage-schema.yaml in the lat container:
```
    OSTREE_CONSOLE:
      type: str
      nullable: False
      pattern: console=.+
```


Quoting from /opt/LAT/SDK/sysroots/x86_64-wrlinuxsdk-linux/usr/lib/python3.10/site-packages/genimage/genimage.py in the lat container:
```
class GenImage(GenXXX):
    # ...
    def _parse_inputyamls(self):
        pykwalify_dir = os.path.join(os.environ['OECORE_NATIVE_SYSROOT'], 'usr/share/genimage/data/pykwalify')
        self.pykwalify_schemas = [os.path.join(pykwalify_dir, 'partial-schemas.yaml')]
        self.pykwalify_schemas.append(os.path.join(pykwalify_dir, 'genimage-schema.yaml'))

        super(GenImage, self)._parse_inputyamls()

```


There is a high likelihood that my suggestion could be rejected by some schema validator.

Hi, apparently the following options are all valid to disable the kernel's console output (and likely that of the user space):

```
console=""
console=null
```

Source: https://elixir.bootlin.com/linux/v5.10.112/source/kernel/printk/printk.c#L2223

I am assuming that single quotes will be fine as well.

However, this commit prompted me to ask: Is our goal to completely disable the console output, or is it only to remove the default setting used by LAT? If it is the latter, perhaps we could use something like the following

```
OSTREE_CONSOLE: ''
```

instead of the following?

```
OSTREE_CONSOLE: console=''
```

Did you mean to have something like the following instead?

```
 OSTREE_CONSOLE: console=tty1
```

(Nested console='console=... does not appear to me like correct kernel command line syntax.)

My understanding now is "Update default labels to be privileged instead of baseline so that the platform apps are deployed successfully regardless of cluster wide security level set by the platform user (e.g. baseline, restricted, privileged)

the feature is enabled by default.
- pod security admission controller is enabled by default
- if more restrictive labels like "baseline" are applied to a namespace, it will deny deployments that needs more privilege
- if no labels exist on a namespace, then pod security admission controller does nothing, essentially acting as if there is a "privileged" label

src/reactive/vault_handlers.py.message:
I think "vault status" is a bit of a vague term, considering a lot of different aspects of vault that the user may be interested in. In this particular case, you're adding the "vault systemd service status" check. Looking at the file in src/files/nagios/check_vault_health.py it retrieves different aspects of the status (assuming the vault service is running), such as if it is sealed, unsealed, initialized, etc (following https://www.vaultproject.io/api-docs/system/health). The disambiguation word for those other aspects of the status is "health", in this case. But from the user's perspective, status can mean all of those things, and the user consuming this action and monitoring just the status may be missing out on checking whether it is sealed. On another note, if that file (invoked by nagios) fails to the check the health, then the service is unavailable. If the user is running nagios, they will get a notification related to that.

Anyway, I think it would be better to have both the docstring and the action description improved to say it is checking the systemd service status.

I think the original bug refers to the exact command as "vault status":
https://www.vaultproject.io/docs/commands/status

and the /sys/health endpoint gives a similar output. I think the expectation here is more of those two methods than the systemd unit status, IMO.

When creating new collectd.conf file to be replaced, this parameter is configure=utf-8, adding that Encoding line that will fail due Python3 incompatibility in Debia, I just set it to undef to not have that tag added.

The ERB file should be static (not dynamically modified). You can put logical statements "if" statements and even loop over arrays within the ERB itself, OR, have the plugin directory variable configured, but you'd need to send new variable through with the plugin library directory.
eg,

kube-config-kubelet.erb:
<% if @is_controller_active.to_s == 'true' or @system_mode == 'simplex' -%>
. .
<%- end -%>

. . .
interface.ifup.erb:
<%- @used_by.each do |iface| -%>
    ifdown <%= iface -%>; ifup <%= iface -%>
<%- end -%>

dockerproxy.conf.erb:

<%- if @http_proxy -%>
Environment="HTTP_PROXY=<%= @http_proxy %>"
<%- end -%>
<%- if @https_proxy -%>
Environment="HTTPS_PROXY=<%= @https_proxy %>"
<%- end -%>
changed to have a variable that will generate collectd.conf with correct value, not changing erb file anymore

./stx-puppet/puppet-manifests/src/hieradata/global.yaml
platform::collectd::params::encoding: "utf-8"

I think line 17 makes this redundant especially since puppet only allows a variable to be set once.
I had it removed but actually global.yaml will add utf-8 and encoding will be added to collectd.conf. That's why I added this line here.

src/lib/charms/layer/magpie_tools.py.message:
The current default value of ping_tries is 1 which means the test finishes in 1 second or so. Probably we don't want to take more time than that in total even if we try multiple ping packets to get an actual percentage of the loss.

My suggestion would be to update the default value to 10 with `-i 0.1` or 20 with `-i 0.05` so we can capture enough data to calculate the percentage in 1 second.

Hmm. I have a second thought on this. In the current implementation it already have a way to modify ping_tries, and when any packet is dropped with those tries it immediately goes into a blocked status, which is expected.

All we need might be having `-i` in the charm config and think about what would be good default values for everyone in terms of `-i`, `-W`, and `-c`.

Btw, when testing this idea, I found a bug as:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/charm-magpie/+bug/1973606
If it helps, there is also already a config for `-w`, so we can already tune `-c` and `-w` as required.  Because of this, I don't think we need to add `-i` and `-W`?
Would you like me to address https://bugs.launchpad.net/charm-magpie/+bug/1973606 in this patch too?  It will be a small fix.
Done
I'm interesting to know the original purpose of this.  Can I safely delete this try/except?

Done
Yep fair enough.

When we discussed about the idea of threshold offline, we assumed iperf since some packet drop or tcp retries are expected. However, now we are testing obvious packet drops like faulty cables, then maybe we can drop the idea of threshold.

What I mean is the expected output in magpie can be:

1. 100% packet loss (suggesting no connectivity like VLAN mis-configuration]

    blocked: icmp failed: ['1']

2. 0% packet loss

    active: icmp ok

3. Some packet loss (e.g. 2 lost packets out of 20)

    blocked: icmp packet loss 10%

How does that sound?

> Some packet loss (e.g. 2 lost packets out of 20)

For this, I had to modify your example slightly, to show the packet loss individual for each host:

    icmp failed: ['25: 25% packet loss', '27: 20% packet loss']

How does this look?

Yeah, I actually didn't know ping tests are mesh type instead of just between each client and the leader. The output looks good to me.

We might want to add a snippet of each status (ok, failed, failed with packet loss) into the commit log just for the record purpose.
Done
Sounds like a solid design to me +1
I suppose this part may require an update to reveal the packet loss percentage into juju status.
Done
Ah yes, good idea.
Although I really like typing, please bear in mind the compatibility issues due to this charm supporting bionic (py3.6).
I removed the type annotations and typing imports due to the concerns here.
I wasn't aware of compatibility issues here - as far as I can tell, `List` is supported in 3.6.  Was there something else you were concerned about?

I feel that this is has only done a 'little' typing (e.g. the return value).  For typing to be of value (even if gradually introduced), then all of the params should be typed, including the Optional[int] for mtu; then curiously, the mtu is coerced to an int on 360??
Done

Yeah typing in python is a joke.  It's probably not even worth adding type parameters here unless we're going to run a type checker (eg. mypy) in CI.

Would you prefer type parameters be added for all here, or just remove them altogether?

> then curiously, the mtu is coerced to an int on 360??

This is likely a result of defensive coding due to not being able to determine if the function is actually always passed an `int`.  I'm not game to change it, because I can't determine it myself.

We tend to, in the OpenStack team, approach comments in the form of:

"""Imperative line describing function.

Description paragraph(s) if necessary

:param addr: ...
:type addr: str   <-- but only if typing not used.
:param timeout: ...
:returns: An integer between 0 and 100 ...

The rationale is that if we (ever) get around to generating docs, we can auto generate the signatures for the the functions using Sphinx plugins.
Ok good to know.  I didn't know there was a convention here, considering the lack of docstrings in this charm. ;)  I'll update it.
Done

> magpie/0*  blocked   executing  0        192.168.151.104         (upgrade-charm) icmp failed: ['1: 10% packet loss', '2: 10% packet loss'], local hostname ok (famous-gibbon), dns ok, iperf leader, mtu: 1500
> magpie/1   blocked   idle       1        192.168.151.102         icmp failed: ['0: 15% packet loss', '2: 25% packet loss'], local hostname ok (up-tahr), dns ok, net mtu ok: 1500, 13675 mbit/s

^^^ 2 out of 3 units got the mtu output while reporting intermittent packet drops.

check_mtu() is called twice in the magpie check one is from the iperf phase to validate the required mtu:
https://github.com/openstack/charm-magpie/blob/465bbb9d6e356a3d308b51d6cfa0113a76879cf0/src/lib/charms/layer/magpie_tools.py#L580

https://github.com/openstack/charm-magpie/blob/465bbb9d6e356a3d308b51d6cfa0113a76879cf0/src/lib/charms/layer/magpie_tools.py#L636
for slightly different purpose.

Two things: First, that setting isn't actually enabled unless you override the puppet parameter (it's $::os_service_default).

But I think a better subject line would focus on the new ability to configure backend_defaults. In my mind, that is the "big feature," and using it to configure use_multipath_for_image_xfer is just the initial use case.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Just leaving a few additional nodes. It'd be nice if you can address these.

- A release note should be added to explain the new class.
- We might want to implement support for enforce_multipath_for_image_xfer as well.

enforce_multipath_for_image_xfer is an odd one, and cinder people typically recommend it *not* be enabled. Nova may choose to use it in its os-brick connections, but mainly to ensure there's no data loss if a vm's only volume connection goes down. With cinder, the connections tend to be ephemeral (only used when downloading an image), so having only a single connection is OK.
I agree with your observation. Let's leave it now.

I looked over [1] in cinder, and there are certainly lots of parameters to choose from. However, it would not make sense to try and implement them all, and many are extremely obscure or unique to specific backends.

The use_multipath_for_image_xfer config is the only one that I believe is "most requested," so I'm fine with this initial implementation.

specs/xena/replication_disabled_reason.r.message: nit: replace with " and Pure Storage among others,"
nit: I think we should rephrase it as "replication is compromised", because strictly speaking the storage supports the replication, it's just that it's not working at that point in time.
-1: In my opinion we should use "administrator" or "operator", since normal users don't usually have access to this information.
nit: "disabled by the administrator"

nit: I don't think that the first use case is something where this spec would actually help, because when an admin is setting up replication for the first time they go check the status and then go into the logs if there is a failure, where they will clearly see the issue as an ERROR log level message since the start of the cinder volume service, which happened just a couple of minutes ago.
-1: "Administrator" or "Operator"
admin

nit: I would explain a bit more why this is important, since that information will be available in the logs anyway.

If I understand the situation correctly the issue is that the issue with the replicas could have happened a long time ago (in a couple of days) and going through the logs to find out when it happened and why it is "not working" can take some time.  Having a message directly here giving a reason can save time for an admin/operator.
nit: a
nit: replace with "which will"
nit: Add: "with the right microversion"
nit: disabled
-1: This doesn't take into account that the DB field needs to be cleared when a driver stops reports a failure in the replication and starts saying that it is working again.

The spec must be explicitly stating that this spec assumes that drivers only report replication disabled when the storage array says so, and that this disabling is not based on the inability of the cinder-volume node to access the node/sites.

?: Should we add a timestamp when the replication disabled was last changed?

This can be useful when it fails for operators to go to the logs around that moment, and it can also be used by operators to know if the replication failed and recovered since the last time the checked.
-1: This requires a new microversion for the REST API change in the service-list command.

I would like to see the work items enumerated:

- Implement cinder-volume code changes: New REST API microversion, DB migration, cidner-volume logic.
- Cinderclient support for new microversion
- Documentation
- Tests

Is this a tempest test or a manual test?  Please say it in the spec.

Because tempest tests need to support backends that don't support replication or have it disabled.  This support can come as a configuration option (flag) in tempest or make the test to expect different things depending on whether the backend is reporting that replication is enabled or not.

Please elaborate a bit more.
nit: "new"
nit: "to be"
